message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Safety Filter: A Unified View of Safety-Critical Control in Autonomous Systems
Paper Abstract: Recent years have seen significant progress in the realm of robot autonomy, accompanied by the expanding reach of robotic technologies. However, the emergence of new deployment domains brings unprecedented challenges in ensuring safe operation of these systems, which remains as crucial as ever. While traditional model-based safe control methods struggle with generalizability and scalability, emerging data-driven approaches tend to lack well-understood guarantees, which can result in unpredictable catastrophic failures. Successful deployment of the next generation of autonomous robots will require integrating the strengths of both paradigms. This article provides a review of safety filter approaches, highlighting important connections between existing techniques and proposing a unified technical framework to understand, compare, and combine them. The new unified view exposes a shared modular structure across a range of seemingly disparate safety filter classes and naturally suggests directions for future progress toward more scalable synthesis, robust monitoring, and efficient intervention.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've successfully performed a web search for "Machine learning." Here are some key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Main Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms: supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Historical Background

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Deep Learning Advances

Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

I've performed a web search for "Safety filter control" and found several relevant results. The term can refer to different contexts:

## Internet Content Filtering

An internet filter is a type of internet censorship that restricts or controls the content an Internet user is capable to access. When this safety filter is activated, it filters out inappropriate links from all of the search results.

## Respiratory Protection

In occupational safety, safety filter control relates to filtering mechanisms in respirators. Mechanical filters are a class of filter for air-purifying respirators that mechanically stops particulates from reaching the wearer's nose and mouth. Mechanical filter respirators retain particulate matter such as dust created during woodworking or metal processing, when contaminated air is passed through the filter material.

## Engineering Controls

In workplace safety, engineering controls are physical changes to the workplace that isolate workers from hazards by containing them in an enclosure, or removing contaminated air from the workplace through ventilation and filtering.

The specific meaning of "safety filter control" depends on the context in which it's being used. Would you like more information about any of these specific applications?

I've completed a web search for "Control theory safe control." Here are the key findings:

## Control Theory Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems, with the aim to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## Safety in Control Theory

The search results reveal several relevant safety concepts:

**Robust Control**: Conservatism is a common approach to safety in the control theory literature in the form of robust control.

**Resilient Control Systems**: A resilient control system is one that maintains state awareness and an accepted level of operational normalcy in response to disturbances, including threats of an unexpected and malicious nature.

**Constrained Control**: Safety-related constraints may be imposed on a system, and the controllability of systems with input and state constraints is studied in the context of reachability and viability theory.

The search results show that safety considerations in control theory involve designing systems that can handle disturbances, maintain stability, respect operational constraints, and operate reliably even under adverse conditions or threats.

**Resilient Control Systems**: A resilient control system is one that maintains state awareness and an accepted level of operational normalcy in response to disturbances, including threats of an unexpected and malicious nature.

**Constrained Control**: Safety-related constraints may be imposed on a system, and the controllability of systems with input and state constraints is studied in the context of reachability and viability theory.

The search results show that safety considerations in control theory involve designing systems that can handle disturbances, maintain stability, respect operational constraints, and operate reliably even under adverse conditions or threats.

An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.

Web search results for query: "Control system engineering"

Links: [{"title":"Control engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_engineering"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Outline of control engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_control_engineering"},{"title":"Instrumentation and control engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instrumentation_and_control_engineering"},{"title":"Industrial process control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_process_control"},{"title":"Advanced process control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_process_control"},{"title":"List of people in systems and control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_people_in_systems_and_control"},{"title":"KFUPM Program of Industrial and Systems Engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KFUPM_Program_of_Industrial_and_Systems_Engineering"},{"title":"Process Systems Design and Control Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_Systems_Design_and_Control_Laboratory"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about control system engineering:

## Definition and Overview

Control engineering, also known as control systems engineering and in some European countries automation engineering, is an engineering discipline that deals with control systems, applying control theory to design equipment and systems with desired behaviors in control environments.(no content)It can be broadly defined or classified as practical application of control theory.

## Applications and Importance

Control engineering plays an essential role in a wide range of control systems, from simple household washing machines to high-performance fighter aircraft.(no content)Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.

## Core Functions

It seeks to understand physical systems, using mathematical modelling, in terms of inputs, outputs and various components with different behaviors; to use control system design tools to develop controllers for those systems; and to implement controllers in physical systems employing available technology.

## System Types

The practice uses sensors and detectors to measure the output performance of the process being controlled; these measurements are used to provide corrective feedback helping to achieve the desired performance. Systems designed to perform without requiring human input are called automatic control systems (such as cruise control for regulating the speed of a car).

## Interdisciplinary Nature

The discipline of controls overlaps and is usually taught along with electrical engineering, chemical engineering and mechanical engineering at many institutions around the world.

I've performed a web search on "Robotics" and found comprehensive information on the topic. Here's an overview of what I found:

## Definition and Overview

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.

## Key Components of Robotics

Robotics usually combines three aspects of design work: mechanical construction (a frame, form or shape designed to achieve a particular task), electrical components that power and control the machinery (used for movement through motors, sensing, and operation), and software (a program that determines when or how a robot does something).

## Specialized Fields

The search results highlight several specialized areas within robotics:

- **Soft Robotics**: Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.

- **Robotic Arms**: A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

- **Humanoid Robots**: Hanson Robotics Limited is a Hong Kong–based engineering and robotics company known for its development of human-like robots with artificial intelligence (AI) for consumer, entertainment, service, healthcare, and research applications.

## Applications and Growth

In the 21st century, investment in robotics companies has grown due to increasing demand for automation.

## Key Components of Robotics

Robotics usually combines three aspects of design work: mechanical construction (a frame, form or shape designed to achieve a particular task), electrical components that power and control the machinery (used for movement through motors, sensing, and operation), and software (a program that determines when or how a robot does something).

## Specialized Fields

The search results highlight several specialized areas within robotics:

- **Soft Robotics**: Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.

- **Robotic Arms**: A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

- **Humanoid Robots**: Hanson Robotics Limited is a Hong Kong–based engineering and robotics company known for its development of human-like robots with artificial intelligence (AI) for consumer, entertainment, service, healthcare, and research applications.

## Applications and Growth

In the 21st century, investment in robotics companies has grown due to increasing demand for automation.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about robot autonomy:

## Definition

An autonomous robot is a robot that acts without recourse to human control. More formally, robots require "a degree of autonomy", which is the "ability to perform intended tasks based on current state and sensing, without human intervention".

## Examples

Historic examples include space probes, while modern examples include self-driving vacuums and cars.(no content)Domestic robots perform tasks that humans regularly perform in non-industrial environments, like people's homes such as for cleaning floors, mowing the lawn and pool maintenance.

## Key Capabilities

For autonomous robots to function effectively, they rely on several critical capabilities:

**Sensing:** Autonomous robots must have a range of environmental sensors to perform their task and stay out of trouble.

**Navigation:** The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation.

**Perception and Decision-Making:** Robots equipped with AI-powered perception systems can process and interpret visual and sensory data from their surroundings, with algorithms developed for object recognition, scene understanding, and real-time tracking.

## Levels of Autonomy

For service robots autonomy ranges from partial autonomy - including human-robot interaction - to full autonomy - without active human robot intervention.

Human operators can still play a role in some autonomous systems; for example, an operator may monitor and take control of the robot remotely in certain situations that the robot cannot resolve by itself such as when it is stuck in an obstacle.

Web search results for query: "Control barrier functions"

Links: [{"title":"Barrier function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_function"},{"title":"Barrier certificate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_certificate"},{"title":"Barrier (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Traffic barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armco_barrier"},{"title":"Crowd control barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crowd_control_barrier"},{"title":"Air barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_barriers"},{"title":"Rectangular potential barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potential_barrier"},{"title":"Barrier analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_analysis"},{"title":"Safety barrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety_barrier"},{"title":"Barrier nursing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barrier_nursing"}]

Based on the search results, I found several types of barrier functions. Here's what "Control Barrier Functions" refers to:

A barrier function is used to prove that a given region is forward invariant for a given ordinary differential equation or hybrid dynamical system—that is, a barrier function can be used to show that if a solution starts in a given set, then it cannot leave that set.

In the context of control theory specifically, these are sometimes called "control barrier functions." There are several different types of barrier functions. One distinguishing factor is the behavior of the barrier function at the boundary of the forward invariant set—one type is called a zeroing barrier function, and another type that goes to infinity as the input approaches the boundary is called a reciprocal barrier function.(no content)Zeroing barrier functions may be preferred in embedded applications as they do not create unbounded values close to the set boundary.

The concept has historical roots: The first result in the field of barrier certificates was the Nagumo theorem by Mitio Nagumo in 1942.

Control barrier functions are mathematical tools used in control systems to ensure that trajectories of dynamic systems remain within safe or specified regions.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

## Lyapunov Stability

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.

### Definition and Concept

Lyapunov stability means that if the system starts in a state x≠0 in some domain D, then the state will remain in D for all time.(no content)Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

### Key Characteristics

Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances.(no content)Lyapunov was a pioneer in successful endeavors to develop a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

### Lyapunov Functions

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

### Applications and Historical Development

The interest in it suddenly skyrocketed during the Cold War period when the so-called "Second Method of Lyapunov" was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems which typically contain strong nonlinearities.(no content)More recently the concept of the Lyapunov exponent (related to Lyapunov's First Method of discussing stability) has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.

### Definition and Concept

Lyapunov stability means that if the system starts in a state x≠0 in some domain D, then the state will remain in D for all time.(no content)Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

### Key Characteristics

Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances.(no content)Lyapunov was a pioneer in successful endeavors to develop a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

### Lyapunov Functions

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

### Applications and Historical Development

The interest in it suddenly skyrocketed during the Cold War period when the so-called "Second Method of Lyapunov" was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems which typically contain strong nonlinearities.(no content)More recently the concept of the Lyapunov exponent (related to Lyapunov's First Method of discussing stability) has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Model Predictive Control:

## Overview

Model predictive control (MPC) is an advanced method of process control that is used to control a process while satisfying a set of constraints.(no content)Model predictive controllers rely on dynamic models of the process, most often linear empirical models obtained by system identification.

## History and Applications

It has been in use in the process industries in chemical plants and oil refineries since the 1980s.(no content)In recent years it has also been used in power system balancing models and in power electronics.

## How It Works

MPC uses the current plant measurements, the current dynamic state of the process, the MPC models, and the process variable targets and limits to calculate future changes in the dependent variables. These changes are calculated to hold the dependent variables close to target while honoring constraints on both independent and dependent variables.(no content)The MPC typically sends out only the first change in each independent variable to be implemented, and repeats the calculation when the next change is required.

## Linear vs. Nonlinear Models

Linear MPC approaches are used in the majority of applications with the feedback mechanism of the MPC compensating for prediction errors due to structural mismatch between the model and the process.(no content)The process can be controlled with nonlinear MPC that uses a nonlinear model directly in the control application.

## Advantages Over Traditional Control

The additional complexity of the MPC control algorithm is not generally needed to provide adequate control of simple systems, which are often controlled well by generic PID controllers. Common dynamic characteristics that are difficult for PID controllers include large time delays and high-order dynamics.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "The Safety Filter: A Unified View of Safety-Critical Control in Autonomous Systems". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Triples Identified:** 10 key technologies and methodologies

The paper was classified as a **contribution** because it proposes a unified technical framework for safety filter approaches, presents novel connections between existing techniques, and suggests new directions for future research in safety-critical control systems.

**Key Technologies & Methodologies Extracted:**

1. **Autonomous Robot** (uses) - Core application domain
2. **Robotics** (uses) - Field where systems are deployed  
3. **Control Theory** (uses) - Foundational mathematical framework
4. **Control Engineering** (uses) - Practical application of control methods
5. **Barrier Function** (uses) - Key safety technique for constraining trajectories
6. **Lyapunov Stability** (uses) - Formal guarantees for system safety
7. **Model Predictive Control** (uses) - Traditional model-based approach
8. **Machine Learning** (uses) - Enables data-driven safety approaches
9. **Autonomous System** (uses) - Broader class of systems requiring safety
10. **Safety Filter** (proposes) - Unified framework introduced by the paper

All triples have been validated and properly mapped to Wikipedia articles with full URLs, entity types, and relevance descriptions. The validation script confirmed all checks passed successfully.
